--- title: "Exploratory Data Analysis" subtitle: "Key Development Indicators (WDI)" author: "Laura Zang" date: 2025-10-06 format: revealjs: theme: [simple, custom.scss] transition: fade slide-number: true incremental: true toc: false width: 1280 height: 720 footer: "© 2025 Laura Zang • Data: World Bank WDI" execute: echo: false bibliography: refs.bib jupyter: python3 --- ## Agenda - Dataset overview - Visualizations - Key insights - References ## Data Overview We analyze three core indicators: - GDP per Capita (US$) - Life Expectancy (years) - Healthcare Expenditure (% of GDP) ::: {#tbl-summary-stats .cell execution_count=2} ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-display execution_count=2} ```{=html}
gdp_per_capita life_expectancy health_expenditure_gdp_share
count 208.000000 217.000000 191.000000
mean 21175.312219 73.108020 6.883157
std 31035.961639 7.942539 3.284450
min 250.634225 18.818000 1.817682
25% 2692.573957 67.788000 4.374079
50% 7713.094217 74.160976 6.500235
75% 28905.928012 78.531000 8.825374
max 226052.001905 85.746000 23.088169
``` Summary statistics for GPD/capita, life expectancy, and health expenditure (% of gdp). ::: ::: ## Correlation Matrix Economic wealth is the strongest driver of longevity (r ≈ 0.57). Health spending share has only a minor connection to both GDP and life expectancy. This suggests that quality and efficiency of healthcare matter more than the proportion of GDP allocated to it. ::: {#tbl-correlations .cell execution_count=3} ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-display execution_count=3} ```{=html}
gdp_per_capita life_expectancy health_expenditure_gdp_share
gdp_per_capita 1.000000 0.571343 0.144464
life_expectancy 0.571343 1.000000 0.157597
health_expenditure_gdp_share 0.144464 0.157597 1.000000
``` Correlation scores between GDP/capita, life expectancy, and health expenditure (% of gdp). ::: ::: ## Pairwise Relationships :::: {.columns} ::: {.column width="40%"} - GDP per capita is strongly and positively associated with life expectancy, while both indicators display only weak relationships with health expenditure as a share of GDP. - The distributions along the diagonal highlight that income is highly skewed, whereas life expectancy and health spending are more evenly distributed across countries. ::: ::: {.column width="60%"} ::: {#cell-fig-pairwise .cell fig-height='2.5' fig-width='2.5' execution_count=4} ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-display} ![Pairwise relationships among GDP per capita, life expectancy, and health expenditure (% of GDP).](presentation_files/figure-revealjs/fig-pairwise-output-1.png){#fig-pairwise width=570 height=570} ::: ::: ::: ::: ## GDP vs. Life Expectancy :::: {.columns} ::: {.column width="50%"} - This graph shows an upward relationship between GDP per capita and life expectancy. Wealthier nations tend to have longer lifespans, though the relationship flattens for very high-income countries. - This pattern directly reflects findings from McKinsey Global Institute’s “Pixels of Progress” report (2022), which notes that “an additional dollar of GDP per capita ‘buys’ more life expectancy at lower levels of income: the slope of the curve gets flatter as GDP per capita grows”. - Improvements in life expectancy are most dramatic in low- and middle-income economies where new income enables access to basic healthcare, sanitation, and nutrition. Once these needs are met, further increases in income yield smaller health gains, and improvements depend on other factors. ::: ::: {.column width="50%"} ::: {#cell-fig-gdp-life .cell execution_count=5} ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-display} ![Relationship between GDP per capita and life expectancy. Source: World Bank WDI (2023).](presentation_files/figure-revealjs/fig-gdp-life-output-1.png){#fig-gdp-life width=656 height=463} ::: ::: ::: ::: ## Health Expenditure vs. Life Expectancy (Clusters) :::: {.columns} ::: {.column width="40%"} Overall: The relationship between health spending and life expectancy varies across country clusters, reflecting differences in health system efficiency. - Cluster 1 (orange): High-income, efficient systems with ~80–85 yrs life expectancy and moderate spending (5–10 % of GDP). - The USA is a clear outlier with highest spending but lower-than-expected life expectancy, consistent with Our World in Data (2020) findings. - Cluster 0 (green): Middle-income, developing systems where higher spending still yields measurable life-expectancy gains. - Cluster 2 (blue): Low-income or inefficient systems that spend more (10–20 % of GDP) yet achieve shorter lifespans (~50–70 yrs). ::: ::: {.column width="60%"} ::: {#cell-fig-health-clusters .cell execution_count=6} ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-display} ![Clusters of countries based on health expenditure (% of GDP) and life expectancy. Source: World Bank WDI (2023).](presentation_files/figure-revealjs/fig-health-clusters-output-1.png){#fig-health-clusters width=797 height=559} ::: ::: ::: ::: ## Key Statistics The U.S. Healthcare Paradox: - Extreme wealth, modest outcomes: The U.S. is one of the richest nations (GDP per capita ≈ $77,900) yet achieves lower life expectancy than its high-income peers. - Diminishing returns: Reflecting McKinsey (2023), further income growth yields smaller health gains once basic needs are met. - High spending, low efficiency: The U.S. spends 16.5% of GDP on healthcare—about double the high-income average—but life expectancy (77.4 years) lags nearly four years behind. - Outlier status: As shown in @fig-health-clusters, the U.S. stands out as an inefficient system, supporting Our World in Data (2024) findings that efficiency and equity, not spending volume, drive future health improvements. ::: {#tbl-usa-comparison .cell tbl-cap='Comparison of the United States with global and high-income averages. Source: World Bank WDI (2023).' execution_count=7} ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-display execution_count=7} ```{=html}
Indicator United States High-income avg Global avg
GDP per capita (US$) 77,860.91 69255.110000 21,175.31
Life expectancy (years) 77.43 81.280000 73.11
Health expenditure (% of GDP) 16.50 8.410000 6.88
``` ::: ::: ## Conclusion - **Global trends:** - Higher GDP per capita is strongly linked to longer life expectancy, but the relationship flattens at high income levels — showing diminishing health returns from wealth. - Health expenditure shares only a weak positive link with longevity, suggesting that how money is spent matters more than how much is spent. - **Cluster insights**: - High-income nations achieve strong outcomes with moderate, efficient spending. - Middle-income countries still gain measurable improvements as investment rises. - Some low-income nations show inefficient spending, with high costs but limited progress. - **The U.S. paradox:** - The United States exemplifies inefficiency — spending 16.5% of GDP on healthcare yet ranking below peers in life expectancy. - Confirms findings from McKinsey (2023) and Our World in Data (2024) that system efficiency, equity, and innovation are now the main drivers of health gains, not wealth alone. [@mckinsey_pixels_progress_ch3] [@ourworldindata_life_expectancy_vs_health_expenditure] [@ourworldindata_us_life_expectancy] - *Economic growth enables better health, but only when paired with efficient, equitable, and innovative healthcare systems.* ## References ::: {#refs} :::
